body: Looks like it's running database garbage collection. Some CPU usage is expected for that.

> Looks like it's running database garbage collection. Some CPU usage is expected for that.

But what's strange is that once it reaches this state, the CPU usage remains high and doesn't decrease, even after days.

It's actually somewhat fascinating, the CPU time is not doing GC but just setting up the bloom filters for the GC, something I'd expect to be pretty much instantaneous. Have you manually tweaked the interval for running GC? (`--debug-db-indirect-gc-interval` or `$STGCINDIRECTEVERY`)

> It's actually somewhat fascinating, the CPU time is not doing GC but just setting up the bloom filters for the GC, something I'd expect to be pretty much instantaneous. Have you manually tweaked the interval for running GC? (`--debug-db-indirect-gc-interval` or `$STGCINDIRECTEVERY`)

Did not use these.

Having the same or a similar issue on Linux with syncthing v1.29.6, where it would use a lot of CPU for long times, and a restart of syncthing immediately fixes it. I recently upgraded from v1.29.3 and don't remember having this issue before, I could be wrong though. I don't know if it cures itself after sometime, because I just restart it, because my fan becomes so loud (Ivy Bridge laptop)... Edit: Like OP, I have this issue while syncthing is not actively syncing anything, the Web GUI shows everything "Up to date".
Take a CPU profile please, or there is nothing to debug.

Here are four CPU profiles from today (not from the Ivy Bridge laptop mentioned above, a slightly newer laptop). The CPU profiles were taken at a time where the CPU usage was high due to syncthing, everything was showing "Up to date" i.e. no active syncing, and nothing else noteworthy was running on the laptop.

- syncthing-cpu-linux-amd64-v1.29.6-033410.pprof: https://0x0.st/8tYC.pprof
- syncthing-cpu-linux-amd64-v1.29.6-033523.pprof: https://0x0.st/8tgr.pprof
- syncthing-cpu-linux-amd64-v1.29.6-230739.pprof: https://0x0.st/8tgs.pprof
- syncthing-cpu-linux-amd64-v1.29.6-230822.pprof: https://0x0.st/8tgz.pprof

In case it matters, here is how I have syncthing configured:

- Connections: set `Sync Protocol Listen Addresses` to `tcp4://:22000, quic4://:22000`
- Connections: disable `Enable NAT traversal`, `Global Discovery` and `Enable Relaying`
- Connections: enable `Local Discovery`
- For most folders, I have set `fsWatcherDelayS` to `0.5` or `1`
Those URLs are all errors for me
@calmh Please try again, I reuploaded. Maybe they got deleted in the meantime. (For some reason I cannot upload them directly here.)
Looks like it's reacting to lots and lots of filesystem notifications...

In case it's useful, here is some basic data about the two synced folders that I use on this device. There is one folder with 290 small files that never change. Apart from this one, no folder contains more than 150 files.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2670c705-c426-49f2-910c-be1927ee03d9)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/eeb57958-9e8d-40f5-b45a-b13bc79dc58c)

I think it's a bug in the watch aggregator where it thinks there are events to handle, but there aren't and it's just spinning. Combined with a very low FSWatcherDelayS set on the folder?

Adding the above profiles for stable storage: 

[profiles.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/20421456/profiles.zip)

rename.from: CPU Usage High with no mission
rename.to: FS notification watch aggregator stuck spinning on timers ("CPU Usage High with no mission")

body: Yes, those two folders both have FSWatcherDelayS set to `0.5`.

While I don't think low delays like this are ever a good idea (at least it's not the minimum 10ms o.O), that's besides the point if there's a bug that keeps the loop spinning - that's not nice at any delay, just less noticeable at higher ones. Would be great if you could provide debug logs when this occurs again, so we can see what's actually going on and hopefully diagnose the issue that way.  
Warning: This will cause a lot of logging, you likely only want to enable it for a short time. Also it will contain file paths, if that's an issue to share (publically or privately) let me know and we'll figure something out.  
First you need to make sure your logs are persistend somewhere, the UI wont work here. This depends on how you run it, on linux typically via systemd (logs in journal). Otherwise you can use `syncthing --paths` to see if it logs to a file and where.  
Then enable `watchaggregator` debug logging, either through the web UI (actions > logs) or by setting the env var `STTRACE=watchaggregator`). While ideally this would be in place when the issue starts, it might not be necessary. And unless you can reproduce the issue at will, it's likely impractical to have it enabled before - what I mean to say is, that if you only enable it after the issue starts, that's still good enough.

@imsodin Thank you for the detailed description. I will collect debug logs next time I notice the issue. However, one of my two laptops just died (both running syncthing), and on the other one (with almost identical settings) the issue did not occur again so far, although it did occur on it before. So maybe it will be some time until I post the logs.

Ok, so I get hundreds of thousands of these within a very short time during those periods with high CPU usage:

```
 Jun 12 16:23:17 mx230 syncthing[1347]: [F34ZW] 2025/06/12 16:23:16.900009 aggregator.go:315: DEBUG: aggregator/"sync/mpixel" (v7tam-6f2yu): Resetting notifyTimer to 0s

 Jun 12 16:23:17 mx230 syncthing[1347]: [F34ZW] 2025/06/12 16:23:16.900126 aggregator.go:315: DEBUG: aggregator/"sync/mpixel" (v7tam-6f2yu): Resetting notifyTimer to 0s

 Jun 12 16:23:17 mx230 syncthing[1347]: [F34ZW] 2025/06/12 16:23:16.900300 aggregator.go:315: DEBUG: aggregator/"sync/mpixel" (v7tam-6f2yu): Resetting notifyTimer to 0s
 Jun 12 16:23:17 mx230 syncthing[1347]: [F34ZW] 2025/06/12 16:23:16.900329 aggregator.go:334: DEBUG: aggregator/"sync/mpixel" (v7tam-6f2yu): No old fs events

 Jun 12 16:23:17 mx230 syncthing[1347]: [F34ZW] 2025/06/12 16:23:16.900354 aggregator.go:334: DEBUG: aggregator/"sync/mpixel" (v7tam-6f2yu): No old fs events
 Jun 12 16:23:46 mx230 systemd-journald[427]: Suppressed 1861312 messages from user@1000.service
```

I have shared that folder only with my phone. It has 71 files and 26 folders and totals about 4 GiB.

Does this help?

I'm a bit lost, time.Duration is an int64, yet watcher delay is float, anything sub 1s gets rounded down to 0, so you just end up going into an infinite loop.

https://go.dev/play/p/X3lB6DW8OKj

Not much more to say here. The person who suggested the config change clearly did think this through:

> It might be mostly free to change the type to float and keep the seconds unit.

With "mostly" doing some very heavy lifting here xD
